10 Days

Mexico for Foodies - 10 Days

A Culinary Journey Through Mexico's Greatest Eating Regions

Mexican cuisine is UNESCO-recognized for good reason. This 10-day culinary journey takes you through the country's three greatest food regions: Oaxaca's ancient moles and mezcal, Mexico City's world-class restaurants and street food, and Puebla's culinary origins. You'll take cooking classes, explore markets, and eat your way through unforgettable meals.

Trip Highlights

  • Learn to make seven moles in Oaxaca cooking class
  • Explore legendary markets (Benito Juárez, La Merced, San Juan)
  • Taste mezcal at traditional palenques
  • Dine at world-renowned restaurants (Pujol, Casa Oaxaca)
  • Master street food: tacos, tlayudas, tortas, tamales
  • Discover mole poblano where it was born
  • Experience chocolate from cacao to cup
Duration
10 Days
Best Time
Year-round; October-November for Día de Muertos food traditions
Budget (Mid-Range)
$2,500-4,000 USD per person

Day-by-Day Itinerary

1

Arrival in Oaxaca

Oaxaca City

Arrive in Mexico's culinary capital. Oaxaca's food traditions are among the world's most complex and ancient. Get oriented, explore the centro, and start your journey with dinner at a top restaurant.

Today's Activities:
  • Arrive Oaxaca airport (OAX) or bus from CDMX
  • Check in to hotel in Centro Histórico
  • Orientation walk: Zócalo, Santo Domingo, Alcalá pedestrian street
  • Chocolate at Mayordomo (watch grinding process)
  • Sunset mezcal at In Situ or Mezcaloteca
  • Dinner at Casa Oaxaca El Restaurante (reserve ahead)
2

Markets & Cooking Class

Oaxaca City

Today is about understanding Oaxacan ingredients. Morning at the legendary markets, then a hands-on cooking class learning to prepare moles, the soul of Oaxacan cuisine.

Today's Activities:
  • Early breakfast: Mercado 20 de Noviembre (tasajo, memelitas)
  • Market tour: Mercado Benito Juárez (chiles, cheese, chapulines)
  • Cooking class with market visit (reserve ahead)
  • Learn mole negro, coloradito, and traditional dishes
  • Enjoy your creations for late lunch
  • Rest and explore Jalatlaco neighborhood
  • Dinner at Itanoní (heirloom corn tortillas)
3

Mezcal Route & Village Food

Santiago Matatlán / Villages

Venture into mezcal country, visiting traditional palenques (distilleries) and artisan villages. Learn the difference between industrial and artisanal mezcal while sampling dozens of varieties.

Today's Activities:
  • Join a mezcal route tour (essential for transportation)
  • Visit 2-3 traditional palenques
  • Learn about agave varieties (espadín, tobalá, etc.)
  • Taste artisanal mezcal made in clay pots
  • Lunch in Santiago Matatlán (mezcal capital)
  • Optional: Stop at artisan village (pottery, textiles)
  • Return to Oaxaca
  • Dinner at Los Danzantes (mezcal-paired dining)
4

Fly to Mexico City

Oaxaca → Mexico City

Morning flight to Mexico City, the world's largest Spanish-speaking city and a culinary powerhouse. Settle into Roma or Condesa and dive into the street food scene.

Today's Activities:
  • Morning flight Oaxaca to Mexico City (1 hour)
  • Check in to hotel in Roma Norte or Condesa
  • Late lunch: Street tacos (El Vilsito, Tacos Orinoco)
  • Walk Roma Norte architecture and food scene
  • Mezcal at Licorería Limantour or La Clandestina
  • Dinner at Rosetta (Italian-Mexican fusion) or Maximo Bistrot
5

Markets & Fine Dining

Mexico City Centro / Polanco

Experience the contrast between Mexico City's ancient markets and world-class fine dining. Morning at legendary La Merced and San Juan markets, evening at one of the World's 50 Best Restaurants.

Today's Activities:
  • Early: La Merced Market (largest in the Americas)
  • Sample everything: fruits, juices, prepared foods
  • San Juan Market (gourmet/exotic ingredients)
  • Lunch at market stalls or Café de Tacuba
  • Rest and prepare for evening
  • Dinner at Pujol (book months ahead) or Quintonil
  • Tasting menu experience with mole madre
6

CDMX Cooking Class & Neighborhoods

Mexico City

Hands-on cooking class focusing on classic Mexican dishes, followed by exploration of neighborhoods and their signature foods.

Today's Activities:
  • Morning cooking class (Mexican Home Cooking, Eat Mexico)
  • Learn salsas, tamales, or mole preparation
  • Lunch from your creations
  • Afternoon: Coyoacán neighborhood exploration
  • Market snacks at Coyoacán market
  • Churros at El Moro (since 1935)
  • Dinner at Contramar (seafood) or Eno
7

Street Food Deep Dive

Mexico City Various

A full day devoted to street food mastery. From morning tacos to late-night tortas, experience the incredible diversity of Mexico City's street food culture.

Today's Activities:
  • Morning: Tacos de canasta (basket tacos) in Centro
  • Mid-morning: Carnitas at Los Cocuyos
  • Lunch: Torta at Tortas Don Polo or La Casa de Toño for pozole
  • Afternoon break and digestive walk
  • Late afternoon: Taquería El Califa de León
  • Night: Tacos al pastor at El Huequito or El Vilsito
  • Optional: Late-night tacos after midnight
8

Day Trip to Puebla

Mexico City → Puebla

Drive to Puebla, birthplace of mole poblano and chiles en nogada. This colonial city has its own distinct culinary identity worth exploring.

Today's Activities:
  • Early drive to Puebla (2 hours)
  • Breakfast: Cemitas at Mercado El Carmen or 5 de Mayo
  • Explore Puebla's talavera pottery and colonial centro
  • Lunch at Meson Sacristía (traditional Poblano)
  • Try original mole poblano
  • Visit candy street (Calle de los Dulces)
  • Optional: Chiles en nogada if in season (Aug-Sept)
  • Return to CDMX for final night
9

Final Food Adventures

Mexico City

Last full day to fill in gaps, revisit favorites, and pick up food souvenirs. End with a memorable final dinner.

Today's Activities:
  • Morning: Return to favorite spots or try something new
  • Visit La Merced or Mercado Roma for souvenirs
  • Buy: mole paste, dried chiles, chocolate, mezcal
  • Lunch at a missed must-try
  • Rest before final evening
  • Farewell dinner: Splurge at Sud 777 or return to favorite
  • Final mezcal at favorite bar
10

Departure

Mexico City → Home

Final morning in Mexico. Squeeze in one last taco before heading to the airport.

Today's Activities:
  • Final breakfast at hotel or neighborhood café
  • Pack food souvenirs carefully
  • Last taco if time allows
  • Transfer to airport

Practical Information

Getting There

Fly into Oaxaca (OAX) and out of Mexico City (MEX), or vice versa. Internal flight between cities is 1 hour.

Getting Around

Walking and Uber in cities. Tours for mezcal route and market visits. ADO bus for Puebla day trip or hire a driver.

Frequently Asked Questions

Will I get sick from street food?

Street food is generally safe, especially at busy stalls with high turnover. Start slow, let your stomach adjust, and avoid raw items the first few days. Busy stands with lines are your safest bet—freshness equals safety.

How do I book top restaurants?

Pujol, Quintonil, and similar restaurants book 2-3 months ahead through their websites. Rosetta, Contramar, and mid-range restaurants take reservations 1-2 weeks out. Have your hotel help with bookings.

I'm vegetarian—will this work?

Mexican cuisine is very meat-focused, but there are options. Markets have incredible produce, there are vegetarian-focused restaurants, and many dishes can be modified. Let cooking classes know in advance. You'll miss some experiences but still eat incredibly well.

How spicy is the food?

Spice levels vary widely. Many dishes aren't spicy at all; heat comes from salsas added at the table. Start mild and work up. Ask 'no picante' if you're sensitive. Oaxaca tends to be less spicy than other regions.
